MrWriteLA

http://www.gottman.com/research/projects/gaylesbian/ 
 Among the findings: 
Gay/lesbian couples are more upbeat in the face of conflict. Compared to straight couples, gay and lesbian couples use more affection and humor when they bring up a disagreement, and partners are more positive in how they receive it. Gay and lesbian couples are also more likely to remain positive after a disagreement. "When it comes to emotions, we think these couples may operate with very different principles than straight couples. Straight couples may have a lot to learn from gay and lesbian relationships," explains Gottman.
 
 Gay/lesbian couples use fewer controlling, hostile emotional tactics. Gottman and Levenson also discovered that gay and lesbian partners display less belligerence, domineering and fear with each other than straight couples do. "The difference on these 'control' related emotions suggests that fairness and power-sharing between the partners is more important and more common in gay and lesbian relationships than in straight ones," Gottman explained.
 
 In a fight, gay and lesbian couples take it less personally. In straight couples, it is easier to hurt a partner with a negative comment than to make one's partner feel good with a positive comment. This appears to be reversed in gay and lesbian couples. Gay and lesbian partners' positive comments have more impact on feeling good, while their negative comments are less likely to produce hurt feelings. "This trend suggests that gay and lesbian partners have a tendency to accept some degree of negativity without taking it personally," observes Gottman. 
 
 Unhappy gay and lesbian couples tend to show low levels of "physiological arousal." This is just the reverse for straight couples. For straights, physiological arousal signifies ongoing aggravation. The ongoing aroused state-including elevated heart rate, sweaty palms, and jitteriness-means partners have trouble calming down in the face of conflict. For gay and lesbian couples this lower level of arousal shows that they are able to soothe one another.
The study is also mentioned in this edition of the radio show This American Life, ( http://www.thislife.org/ra/261.ram ) which also features other marriage-related features (same-sex and otherwise), including an especially trenchant monologue by Adam Felber, which can also be read here: http://www.felbers.net/mt/archives/000505.html.

post_info.post_title: 12-year-study shows gay couples are better at dealing with their conflicts

MrWriteLA

This gay marriage thing is tearing my wife and me apart. Now, because of activist judges in Massachusetts and overzealous officials in San Francisco, our union is hanging on by the thinnest of threads.
 
 Back in the simpler days of 2002, when we were planning our wedding, Jeanne and I used to coo fondly at each other about the joys that lay ahead. It wasn't that we were unsupportive of our gay friends, no. We were just looking forward to the government's validation of our relationship's specialness - a license that affirmed that the two of us had made a unique and personal eternal vow to each other. Something uniquer and specialer than any of our homosexual acquaintances could ever even hope for. 
 
 We're all for the separation of church and state, naturally, but if the government doesn't define marriage as the sacred union between a man and a woman, who will? Are Jeanne and I expected to treasure our union solely on the basis of our deep love, personal beliefs, public vows, and the government's blessing? Sorry, Judge Pinkypants, but that's just not good enough. Not for us. We need to know that we've got something that's only available to 90% of the population, the select and upstanding few.
 
 Sure, some of us are criminals. Murderers, even. Some of us have committed rape, beaten children, tattooed swastikas on our bodies, abused animals, broken into houses, bilked the government out of millions of tax dollars, lied under oath, cheated on previous spouses, dishonored our fathers and mothers, failed to keep the Sabbath holy, mowed down pedestrians in our SUV's while intoxicated, coveted our neighbors' stuff, gotten ourselves put on death row, sold military secrets to the Chinese, urinated in public places, beaten up people who looked or sounded different than us, and sold drugs in schoolyards.
 
 But we're straight, and that means we can get married. And that's special. Or, at least it was. Jeanne and I could look around at other married couples - at least the ones that aren't currently dealing with serial infidelity, divorce, spousal abuse, or bigamy - and think to ourselves, "Yes, that's what we're striving for. That kind of sanctity." 
 
 Are some gay people serious about their commitment to each other? Sure, of course, that's not the point. Let me give you an example. Jeanne and I know this couple, these two men. They've been together for years and years, longer than we have. They live on a farm in Pennsylvania and treasure their time together. They're loved by their community, have saved lives as members of the local fire department and have opened their home to youth groups from the city. They've built a life together based on love and trust. BUT - and here's my point - they're gay. They're both men. And if they're allowed to marry someday, where does that leave us, my wife and me? See what I'm saying? It'd cheapen everything we have. 
 
 And that's not a knock on gay people. No no no. America loves its gays. Look at the TV, with all those funny gay people on "Will and Grace," and "XXXXX as Folk," and "XXXXX Eye for the Straight Guy." They're funny! Funny, colorful people - they're nature's clowns, really. Like penguins.
 
 And we don't allow penguins to marry, do we? No, these are dark times in my household. My wife and I look at each other with haunted, suspicious eyes, feeling like we've bought a whole bunch of shares in a stock that is about to be devalued. Suddenly, the eternal, personal vows that we swore to each other will mean very little. We'll basically become roommates who happen to wear matching rings, while meanwhile out our window we'll see gays and penguins feeding each other wedding cake willy-nilly on our very own street corner.
 
 That's why we need a Constitutional amendment that will protect marriage for straight people. Until we have the right to enter that sacred union, violate it, exit it, and enter it again with somebody else, again and again, regardless of what crimes we commit, until we're too old and feeble to mouth the words, "I do," - unless we have that right and gay people don't, then there is truly nothing sacred in the United States of America.

Jaxian

Here is a study comparing same-sex marriages to opposite-sex marriages. 
 
 Also, here is a fictional testimony detailing why people oppose same-sex marriage.

 
 I'm not sure that the findings of that top study are necessarily the reflection of homosexuality at all. I would imagine that the results of the study are not caused by homosexuality but by a more liberal mindset. The mindset of those who accept homosexuality, especially those who engage in it themselves, is more likely to be liberal than conservative; it is less likely to condemn or get angry over the actions of another because it does not see a problem with those actions. I would argue that the conservative mindset enforces the idea that things must happen and be done in a certain manner, and when something outside of that realm of security occurs, they become much more upset over it. If we factor in such ideological differences, we might expect to see the same results in comparing a very liberal-minded opposite-sex couple that we would seeing a same-sex couples. The cause then, may not be the sexual orientation or sexual composition of the marriage, but the mindset of the individuals involved.
 
 As for the second article, it is undoubtedly going to be insulting to some here, but I do think that it brings up a very good point: that there really is not a good reason to deny same-sex marriage. The article hopefully does a good job of showing how the arguments of many who oppose same-sex marriage sound to many who support it; I know I have often felt as that article portrays, that my opponent is stating things in a genuine and concerned tone, yet not really providing a reason to deny same-sex marriage. The implications of such an argument might indeed imply that same-sex couples just aren't real relationships. So when you read that article, try not to get offended if you oppose same-sex marriage. Try to figure out why that article exists and how your view of same-sex marriage is different from what is portrayed there.

What is the point of this? Is this supposed to make people want to be gay? This is like white supremacist propaganda saying how white people were so much better at some things than everyone else.

 
 The point of it was likely to show that same-sex relationships are not harmful or worse that opposite-sex relationships, and therefore they should not be less qualified to raise children or recieve equal rights.
 
 
And all of these findings are based on a study of 21 gay and 21 lesbian couples. Can you say "bogus statistical significance". Any scientist making universal statements about any group from such a small population ought to have their scientific credentials revoked.

 Such a study would likely be incredibly difficult to perform on a large group, and anyone who claimed to have done so would be more likely to need his license revoked. It is also unjustified to dismiss the findings simply because the sample was not large enough to be representative, for even with a small sample, it is more likely that you will get the correct results than the incorrect results, assuming the sample was drawn randomly.
 
 However, it is certainly valid to question the results of the finding based on the sample size, and I don't see a problem with pointing that out, especially since this was indeed a small sample.

 All relationships are not alike. Those of one group certainly can, on average, be "better" than others. That, of course, is dependent on what one considers "good". When they are, it's not because of the type but because that type has a higher probability of exhibiting some characteristic that helps in developing whatever aspect of the relationship leads to some beneficial outcome.
 
 Same-sex relationships are, by their very nature, more about equals than opposite-sex relationships are. There are quite a few benefits to a relationship when more issues are handled as a negotiation between equals. There are some clear advantages to this in coming to compromises. There are also some clear disadvantages when that compromise can't be reached.

 You did notice the "on average" part of what I said, right? And the bit about "more about equals"? I'm not suggesting that ALL gay relationships reflect this nor that they should. It remains true, however, that MORE gay relationships than straight relationships involve two people who see themselves as roughly equal, or at least not bound by traditional societal roles based solely on gender. Whether it's because of self-awareness or because two men both adopting traditional roles would lead to a lot of garbage being taken out but very little cooking getting done, gay couples tend to engage in a more balanced, negotiated process of figuring out who is going to do which chores, etc. The very willingness to do so leads to fewer tensions.
 
 It's not such a horrible thing for one kind of couple to learn something from another kind of couple. Equality before the law and in society does not mean that everyone turns out the same.

While not trying to put words into zelmas mouth, I'd state that the objection to gay issues is that many homosexuals appear to be one dimensional people who's entire self identity is based on their gayness.
 They can't seem to have a conversation that doesn't gravitate towards homosexuality or gay issues. Whether or not it's pertient to the current conversation or not.
 
 The objection isn't to you being gay, it's to you ONLY being gay.
 And, quite often, the young immature attention seekers who think they have to justify themselves to 'what ever' are the overt and loud ones. 
 Just as like was mentioned about heterosexuals who continue on and on and on about their male (or female) prowess.
 
 I support equality in treatment personally for homosexuals. Support civil unions (for hetero or homos) as well as equal treatment of marriage (for hetero or homos). I support adoption rights for homosexual couples even if I'm a little leary that homosexuality has stronger potential to be a learned behavior as opposed to a genetic predisposition.
 
 But, just as I find slight offense in heterosexuals displaying overt sexual behavior in public, I hold the same mild offense of homosexuals for the same causes. I just don't like social displays of intimacy.
 
 If your family disowns you, sorry. Go off as you said and do your own thing.
 I'm offended by my mothers overt racism and distance myself from her on that issue. Even though I am not involved in a multi-racial relationship or ever was. But, then again, I'd do the same if she was a sports fanatic and I find spectator sports to be annoying in the extream.
 
 If you're asked a direct question, feel free to answer it as fully as your desire. They asked for it. But, do you feel the need to volunteer all sorts of personal information 'Just because'?
 
 I recall several years back having a conversation with a male and I mentioned specifically 'spouse or partner' to him in an open conversation about significant others and ended up recieving an earfull of hateful rants about how he doesn't legally have a spouse since he's homosexual and how dare I mention 'spouse' to him at all. Shouldn't I have 'known' he was homosexual?
 Instead of being something simple, it was a self identity issue and political crusade. Instead of being a individual with a multi-fauceted personality, he was a sterotyped one dimensional cartoon character with a chip on his shoulders the size of a mountain and totally unable to see a natural ally.
 
 But, as for what you volunteer in answering a question...I don't always say 'I went to see the movies with my WIFE...or even children' when asked what I did. Even if that's specifically what I did.
 But, then again, I also would have answered 'Did my taxes.' Not, 'Sat at home wondering how I can cheat the IRS out of some extra money while doing my taxes.' 
 Or, I might say, 'Cynthia and I went to the movies'. If they don't know who she is, they can ask. Then the burden of the answer is upon them...they asked specifically for it. emoticon_xangel 
 It's tact. Tailoring the answer to the specific questioner.
 
 Lord knows when my Boss asks what I did last saturday, I'd like to respond 'Picked up some hot chic as X bar (who turned out to be your daughter) with my wife, took her home to my house boy and doused ourselves with vegatable oil. Had an orgy and smoked some weed while plotting to steal office supplies and sabotage your car.' Even if none of it's true.
 
 But, as to responding that you went to a gay bar...get over yourself already.
 I've responded doing the same and I'm heterosexual.
 Yeah, I've been to gay bars. So what?
 
 I just find it kind of amazing that just being yourself happens to involve a large dose of 'being gay'.
 A large part of being 'me' is being an *******. But, I don't go about overtly and directly advertising it. It just sort of shines through. You'd have to be extreamly dense not to pick up on it.
 
 Hmmmm. Maybe I should champion ******* rights. We really don't get treated fairly in the world. I mean, people won't be my friend simply because I'm an *******. And, there's this stereotype that's been perpetuated that we can't have a decent relationship with someone else purely because we're *******s.
 I can disprove that easily. I have a fairly decent relationship with someone else (living) who's the polar opposite of me.
 Yep, I'm willing to bet I've recieved far more discrimination due to being an ******* than anyone here's recieved for merely being homosexual.
 I can even be imprisoned for being an ******* to a judge under the stupid contempt of court clause. All perfectly legal. And, let me tell you jail isn't a nice place to visit for any period of time. But, it's hard to not find someone who thinks that all *******s deserve to be there.
 The worst thing is, getting the group of like minded people to organize to fight this rampant discrimination. But, then again, they're all *******s and I personally wouldn't lift a finger to help the lot of them.
 
 So, in conclusion. I'm perfectly willing to accept any homosexual if they're willing to accept me as an *******.
 Want to bet you'd go 'straight' before I'd start being nice?
 
 Note: ******* is equally replacable by jerk, wanker or any other obnoxious and insensitive title.

 Depends on the situation.
 
 One Saturday afternoon I had invited several of the Mexican engineers who worked for me to a BBQ. We had a keg of beer and the charcoal going when 2 young Mormon missionaries showed up. We graciously denied acceptance of their tracts, telling them they would be beter served by giving them to someone who would be interested in them. It was a hot day, and I offered them some iced tea. We all sat around the patio and listened to them talk about their adventures in their travels. They ended up staying for the BBQ and we all had an enjoyable time.
 
 Another Saturday morning, I had just finished my shower and was shaving with only a towel wrapped around me. There was a knock on my door. I went to answer it with the door shielding my body from view. 2 young Jehovah's Wittnesses females pushed through the door and attempted to enter my house. I slammed the door closed and one of then had their hand in the way and ended up with 2 broken fingers. I called for an ambulance and the police and had them arrested for attempted forceable tresspassing. Yes, I pressed charges and they were fined by the judge.
 
 I rest MY case. emoticon_xangel
Jaxian

Yes, I pressed charges and they were fined by the judge.

 
 Ack! Well, you were certainly well within your rights to do that, but doesn't two broken fingers seems like more than adequate punishment, even though it was an accident?
wsm2506

Ack! Well, you were certainly well within your rights to do that, but doesn't two broken fingers seems like more than adequate punishment, even though it was an accident?

 
 I felt they needed to know the difference between freedom of religious expression and right to privacy.
JPSartre12

I wouldn't say that every day is a straight day; I would say that gay days exist for a reason. I would say that it is an attempt both to bring visibility to homosexuals, which can help them politically as well as offering an attempt to allow homosexuals to meet each other, which is often very difficult to do. It can further help encourage people who often feel very alone in their life.
 
 In truth, there just isn't a need for this sort of thing for straight people. Straight people make up the vast majority. Now that I think about it, I guess Joebrummer has a point: a bunch of straight people getting together is really no different from most days.

 
 Ah, but isn't Disney giving you a "right" that straight people don't get? I don't recall Disney having a "No gay Day". Gays are allowed in the park every day, but straights are forbidden on some days? emoticon_rolleyes 
 
 See how ridiculous the whole us vs them argument becomes?
Jaxian

Ah, but isn't Disney giving you a "right" that straight people don't get? I don't recall Disney having a "No gay Day". Gays are allowed in the park every day, but straights are forbidden on some days? emoticon_rolleyes 
 
 See how ridiculous the whole us vs them argument becomes?

 
 Everyone is allowed in the park on gay day. :) It's really just Disney's ploy to attract more people to their parks, most people in the park don't even know it is gay day.
 
 But I agree that there should be no "us vs. them" argument; that's why I think we need to give everyone the same rights. I'm not fighting against anyone, I'm only fighting for people.
BobNelson2

Ah, but isn't Disney giving you a "right" that straight people don't get? I don't recall Disney having a "No gay Day". Gays are allowed in the park every day, but straights are forbidden on some days? emoticon_rolleyes 

 
 You know, you really should see an ophthalmologist. All that eye rolling can't be healthy.
 
 Of course straight people aren't forbidden, silly. In fact, from what I understand, Gay Days are quite popular for heterosexual couples and families. Apparently, having all those gay people around makes for a fun time.
 
 
See how ridiculous the whole us vs them argument becomes?

 
 It certainly was ridiculous when Disneyland used to expel same-sex couples...
BobNelson2

Everyone is allowed in the park on gay day. :) It's really just Disney's ploy to attract more people to their parks, most people in the park don't even know it is gay day.

 
 Well, first of all, it's not a Disney event. The company itself does not sponsor the activities, though they are now welcoming.
 
 Here's some history:
 
 http://www.gaydays.com/about/history.html
 
 (Like so many gay-related things, it's become too commercially oriented for my tastes.)
joebrummer

Well, first of all, it's not a Disney event. The company itself does not sponsor the activities, though they are now welcoming.
 
 Here's some history:
 
 http://www.gaydays.com/about/history.html
 
 (Like so many gay-related things, it's become too commercially oriented for my tastes.)

 Bob, you would be surprised. Not commercial at all. If you are good at travel plans. The commercialism is a good thing. South west seems to cater to the gay crowd with some good airfares, after that I never really see anything to commercial. Of course I don't go to pleasure Island either, I hear it is kinda of wild and crazy for commercialism there, but we are too old for the chicken thing.
Zardoz

As to equal rights for gays.
 
 They pretty much have the same rights as heterosexuals do. 
 In regards to marriage, they can marry a member of the opposite sex just like heteros can. For some reason, I as a hetero can't marry a member of the same sex...just because.
 
 However, since marriages are no longer arrainged and heteros are allowed to marry a 'person of their choice' for nearly all intents and purposes, I support the ability for homosexuals to do the same. AND, if for some reason, a hetero decideds to marry another hetero...who cares.
 If there are complaints about tax rights, just drop it all from tax law. Keep government out of it. And, I do enjoy tax benifits for being legally married. As do many childless heterosexual couples. 
 
 As to adoption. There have been several cases of known homosexuals adopting children. Heck, a gym coach at the local elementary school where my children went adopted a child...she's gay. However, it is easier to adopt if you're married.
 As an adoptive parent of 3 and a person opposed to abortion and institutionalized child care such as orphanages and youth shelters, I support anyone who can pass background checks and family studies being able to adopt. If you're a flaming homosexual who spends all your free time at the bars and engage in risky social behavior with multiple partnets, I'd deny you. But, I'd do the same to a heterosexual who did the same thing with the opposite sex.
 
 As to 'Gay Day' events. While in actuality heteros are also allowed to many of these, when casually mentioned, it smacks of hypocracy on the surface if one is lead to believe that heteros are not allowed.
 Gives the impression that gays don't want equal rights but special attention.
 A good friend several years back, who is gay, was lamenting the issue of discrimination in the work force for homosexuals. Several weeks after his rant, he ended up working for a person in the local mall who ONLY hired gays. A case of obvious reverse discrimination.
 
 
 As to wsm2506's prosecution of the JWs, a good offense is better than a good defense. Prosecuting circumnavigates having to deal with a lawsuit for breaking her fingers while she was on his property. He wins and she loses ground to stand on since her injuries happened while in the commision of a crime.
 Sad it happened but, sometimes it's almost necessary. Might teach her not to be so pushy. Or, it'll justify her beliefs and make her feel all martyr like.
 I've never had much problems with bible pushers being pushy people but, my Irish wolfhound did take a dislike to the JW lady. The only one he's had problems with. Eventually he chased her off after 2 years. But, a 150 lb dog would do that to anyone he didn't like. But, I will give her credit for butting heads with my christian fundy wife for that long. Gave me all sorts of pleasure watching them have theological discussions. emoticon_xangel
Jaxian

I agree with just about everything you said, Zardoz, so I'll make just a few comments.
 
 
As to equal rights for gays.
 
 They pretty much have the same rights as heterosexuals do.

 
 Remember though that the same rights is not the same thing as equal rights. I think you understand that there is inequality, but I just mean that it is not wrong for someone to say that gays do not have equal rights.
 
 
A good friend several years back, who is gay, was lamenting the issue of discrimination in the work force for homosexuals. Several weeks after his rant, he ended up working for a person in the local mall who ONLY hired gays. A case of obvious reverse discrimination.

 
 It is indeed reverse discrimination, but it is likely that someone would only hire gays in protest of workforce discrimination against them; this would not be a common situation by any measure.
